messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Information Theoretic Limits of Cardinality Estimation: Fisher Meets ShannonThis work was supported by NSF grants CCF-1637546 and CCF-1815316.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Estimating the cardinality (number of distinct elements) of a large multiset is a classic problem in streaming and sketching, dating back to Flajolet and Martin’s classic Probabilistic Counting (𝖯𝖢𝖲𝖠𝖯𝖢𝖲𝖠\mathsf{PCSA}) algorithm from 1983. In this paper we study the intrinsic tradeoff between the space complexity of the sketch and its estimation error in the random oracle model. We define a new measure of efficiency for cardinality estimators called the Fisher-Shannon (𝖥𝗂𝗌𝗁𝖥𝗂𝗌𝗁\mathsf{Fish}) number ℋ/ℐℋℐ\mathcal{H}/\mathcal{I}. It captures the tension between the limiting Shannon entropy (ℋℋ\mathcal{H}) of the sketch and its normalized Fisher information (ℐℐ\mathcal{I}), which characterizes the variance of a statistically efficient, asymptotically unbiased estimator. Our results are as follows. • We prove that all base-q𝑞q variants of Flajolet and Martin’s 𝖯𝖢𝖲𝖠𝖯𝖢𝖲𝖠\mathsf{PCSA} sketch have 𝖥𝗂𝗌𝗁𝖥𝗂𝗌𝗁\mathsf{Fish}-number H0/I0≈1.98016subscript𝐻0subscript𝐼01.98016H_{0}/I_{0}\approx 1.98016 and that every base-q𝑞q variant of (Hyper)LogLog has 𝖥𝗂𝗌𝗁𝖥𝗂𝗌𝗁\mathsf{Fish}-number worse than H0/I0subscript𝐻0subscript𝐼0H_{0}/I_{0}, but that they tend to H0/I0subscript𝐻0subscript𝐼0H_{0}/I_{0} in the limit as q→∞→𝑞q\rightarrow\infty. Here H0,I0subscript𝐻0subscript𝐼0H_{0},I_{0} are precisely defined constants. • We describe a sketch called Fishmonger that is based on a smoothed, entropy-compressed variant of 𝖯𝖢𝖲𝖠𝖯𝖢𝖲𝖠\mathsf{PCSA} with a different estimator function. It is proved that with high probability, Fishmonger processes a multiset of [U]delimited-[]𝑈[U] such that at all times, its space is O​(log2⁡log⁡U)+(1+o​(1))​(H0/I0)​b≈1.98​b𝑂superscript2𝑈1𝑜1subscript𝐻0subscript𝐼0𝑏1.98𝑏O(\log^{2}\log U)+(1+o(1))(H_{0}/I_{0})b\approx 1.98b bits and its standard error is 1/b1𝑏1/\sqrt{b}. • We give circumstantial evidence that H0/I0subscript𝐻0subscript𝐼0H_{0}/I_{0} is the optimum 𝖥𝗂𝗌𝗁𝖥𝗂𝗌𝗁\mathsf{Fish}-number of mergeable sketches for Cardinality Estimation. We define a class of linearizable sketches and prove that no member of this class can beat H0/I0subscript𝐻0subscript𝐼0H_{0}/I_{0}. The popular mergeable sketches are, in fact, also linearizable.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Mergeable summaries",
        "The space complexity of approximating the frequency moments",
        "Statistical theory: a concise introduction",
        "Compact dictionaries for variable-length keys and data with applications",
        "A multi-round communication lower bound for gap Hamming and some consequences",
        "Mathematical statistics: Basic ideas and selected topics. 2d. ed. vol. 1 prentice hall",
        "Distinct-value synopses for multiset operations",
        "Counting distinct elements in a data stream",
        "Reductions in streaming algorithms, with an application to counting triangles in graphs",
        "Optimal streaming and tracking distinct elements with high probability",
        "On the resemblance and containment of documents",
        "Statistical Inference, 2nd Ed.",
        "A statistical analysis of probabilistic counting algorithms",
        "Distinct counting with a self-learning bitmap",
        "Efficient estimation of the cardinality of large data sets",
        "Tighter estimation using bottom k𝑘k sketches",
        "A minimal variance estimator for the cardinality of big data set intersection",
        "Approximate aggregation techniques for sensor databases",
        "Size-estimation framework with applications to transitive closure and reachability",
        "All-distances sketches, revisited: HIP estimators for massive graphs analysis",
        "From independence to expansion and back again",
        "Elements of Information Theory (Second Edition)",
        "Loglog counting of large cardinalities",
        "Concentration of Measure for the Analysis of Randomized Algorithms",
        "Combinatoire analytique et algorithmique des ensembles de données. (Multivariate holonomy, applications in combinatorics, and analysis of algorithms)",
        "New cardinality estimation methods for HyperLogLog sketches",
        "Bagminhash - minwise hashing algorithm for weighted sets",
        "Bitmap algorithms for counting active flows on high-speed links",
        "HyperLogLog: the analysis of a near-optimal cardinality estimation algorithm",
        "On adaptive sampling",
        "Probabilistic counting algorithms for data base applications",
        "Order statistics and estimating cardinalities of massive data sets",
        "Estimating simple functions on the union of data streams",
        "Data Streams as Random Permutations: the Distinct Element Problem",
        "HyperLogLog in practice: algorithmic engineering of a state of the art cardinality estimation algorithm",
        "Tight lower bounds for the distinct elements problem",
        "Optimal bounds for Johnson-Lindenstrauss transforms and streaming problems with subconstant error",
        "An optimal algorithm for the distinct elements problem",
        "Back to the future: an even more nearly optimal cardinality estimation algorithm",
        "Cardinality estimation using Gumbel distribution",
        "An optimal cardinality estimation algorithm based on order statistics and its full analysis",
        "Arithmetic coding revisited",
        "Synopsis diffusion for robust aggregation in sensor networks",
        "Anti-presistence: history independent data structures",
        "Simple and efficient cardinality estimation in data streams",
        "Cardinality estimation",
        "Near-optimal compression of probabilistic counting sketches for networking applications",
        "Apache DataSketches: A software library of stochastic streaming algorithms. https://datasketches.apache.org/",
        "Streamed approximate counting of distinct elements: beating optimal batch methods",
        "Asymptotic Statistics",
        "Arithmetic coding for data compression",
        "Estimating cardinality for arbitrarily large data stream with improved memory efficiency",
        "Fisher information properties",
        "A note on new Bernstein-type inequalities for the log-likelihood function of Bernoulli variables"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Information Theoretic Limits of Cardinality Estimation: Fisher Meets ShannonThis work was supported by NSF grants CCF-1637546 and CCF-1815316., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
